description.narrative:
Organisation Olof Palmes Internationella Center (OPIC) har till Sida ansökt om finansiering av 34 miljoner kronor för att utföra programmet för Serbien 2016-2021. Projektet är en förtsättning på tidigare stöd med fokus på ökat åtnjutande av mänskliga rättigheter och stärkta möljigheter att utöva demokratiskt inflytande. OPIC har en unik kompetens och lång praktisk erfarenhet av demokratiutveckling och fattigdomsbekämpning och det ger OPIC goda möjligheter att arbeta för målet för svenskt utvecklingssamarbete - att bidra till att skapa förutsättningar för fattiga människor att förbättra sina levnadsvillkor.
OPICs förslag ligger i linje med den svenska resultatstrategin för reformsarbete med Öseuropa, Västra Balkan och Turkiet för perioden 2014-2020 som anger stöd till stärkt demokrati, ökad respekt för mänskliga rättigheter och mer utvecklad rättsstat. Projektet är mycket relevant för Serbiens EU integrationsagenda eftersom ett aktivt civilsamhälle kan spela en viktig roll i genomförandet och uppföljningen av nationella och EU-prioriteringar och strategier.

new OPIC Serbia 2016-2021: Over the past four years, Serbia did not make significant improvements when it comes to reform processes and European Integrations. The existing focus on transparency and accountability, citizen participation and the legitimacy of civil society organisations will therefore remain, further emphasizing the importance of activism, movement building and membership.

Serbian civil sector continue to face substantial obstacles in their efforts to participate in the EU reform process. The Olof Palme International Center (OPC) continued supporting the democratic develop-ment in Serbia in 2020 as committed in the application for 2016-2021 with a focus on the following thematic areas: transparency and accountability, socio-economic/labour rights and citizen/popular participation. The focus is based on previous experiences, a continuous analysis of current political developments and overall guided by the International strategy of the Olof Palme International Center. The OPC’s theory of change is firmly rooted in the conviction that social transformation and development is achieved through collective organising. When people come together, they gain the power to shape the societies in which they live, and thereby their own lives. The main tool is supporting partner organisations that can be part of forming a vibrant civil society contributing to the process of democratic consolidation. The thematic focus remains on the following thematic areas: transparency and accountability, labour rights and popular participation. The focus on achieving programme results, based on flexibility and sensitivity towards existing needs, is mainly done through partnership with local CSO’s. At the same time OPC’s regional and international networks offers a highly valued platform for exchanging experiences between partners in the region, which seems much needed in the Western Balkans and for the positioning of Serbia. OPC supported 16 partner organisations through direct projects, and a complete project list is enclosed with the report. The Amendment to the initial agreement between the OPC and Swedish Embassy in Belgrade was signed in December 2020, which extended the Cooperation Agreement for additional two years and added 10 million SEK to the total budget. The OPC operates similar programmes in Serbia, Kosovo and Albania as part of its Balkan strategy, It is the Embassy assessment that one added value is also that OPIC uses the partners from the different countries and programmes to share experiences and to facilitate possible alliances on specific topics. One added value for the programme is also OPC overall experience and knowledge related to organising civil society for social change, and also in providing access to international network of sister organisations and institutions.

description.narrative: OPC reports that the project implementation continues in accordance with theactivity plan and the budget, and in line with the grant agreement. COVID19 situationcaused mainly reschedluing and move to online activities, but no shift of the programme focus. There are no major delays in the programme and no considerable deviations in plans. Sida welcomes our cooperation partner to adapt to reality. In the Embassy dialog with OPC there are no issues that remain unaddressed. OPC displays openess and transparency in dialog, and capacity and willingness to continuously strengthen the organisation. All partners managed to continue their work as organisations and on the le vel of projects. That proved that their sustainability is not so fragile and that their commitment is strong. Moving so many activities to the online world was challenging for several reasons but most of the difficulties were surpassed with good communication and coordination. Video c onferences were a good replacement and created conditions for projects to be implemented in line with the plans. Still, decrease of attention a nd general fatigue with such working environment grew over time. Such approach was necessary but it is certain that the quality of work will improve once it becomes possible to have conferences, public debates and other sim ilar activities in the real world. The OPC programme partners can be divided into two groups. The first one gathers the organisations that are mostly mid size, rooted in their communities for a longer period and have adequate systems for administration and financial management in place, their work is based on strategic management and governance and they apply internal democratic practices. Then there is a second, smaller group of organisations with less experience and with still not fully developed internal administrative capacities, but with hig h level of enthusiasm and energy, willing to grow as organisations and bringing new ideas and approaches into the Vision of the programme. Political and social processes are transparent and participatory, reflecting the rights and interests of empowered and organized citizens that hold duty bearers accountable. Mission of programme. To strengthen the capacity and legitimacy of civil society organisations and support activities that ensure the participatory nature of political and social processes and the accountability of duty bear-ers. Civil society organisations will mobilize citizens and increase popular participation in decision-making, improve transparency and accountability and ensure socio-economic rights/labour rights. Some examples of reported results in the reporting period: With the support of the OPC programme to the strategic planning of the organisation Becej Youth Association has strengthened its internal administration and financial management This process has increased their visibility and representation on national level which attracted the attention of the swiss donor Helvetas who now support BYA with an administrative grant to further improve managem ent and sustainability. Also, gender equality is now a part of the program, and BYA improved both when it comes to gender equality inside the organisation and started with awareness raising and advocacy for improved gender equality in Becej and its surroun dings (Target area 1) Juzne Vesti had a substantial increase of their legitimacy and representation during 2020. One of the project adaptation to COVID was used to send correspondents to Belgrade in the time when people were spending more time with media than ever, wanting to know how to act in the pandemic. The correspondents used a chance to ask the questions relevant to citizens in southern and eastern Serbia This influenced the increase in the popularity of Južne vesti, with the growth of fans o n social networks for almost 15 000 users in less than 10 days. 2020 was a also year that really meant alliances. JV had personal meetings with individuals or teams from different CSOs and media. These meetings also included the necessary support for bette r cooperation between the media and citizens, covid analysis, but also legal support, moral dilemmas about reporting, operational support and work on socialnetworks. (Target areas 1 and 3) Center for Dignified Work solved an important problem of innovati on and modernisation of its website, and thus for the first time gathered in one place all the valuable information and results of previous projects and activities. Gender equality policies have been respected as when it comes to all positions i n CDW projects, while the transparency of the organization's work has been significantly increased by already mentioned development of a new website. CDW gathered, during the implementation of projects in previous years, a significant number of associates who share the core values we stand for and actively represent the interests of workers in their fields of activity. They could become new members in 2021, as well as members of the new bodies of the organization. (Target areas 1 and 3) Toplica Center was ranked number 35 in the world in the 2020 Top Transparency and Good Governance Think Tanks rated by the University of Pennsylvania. https://repository.up-enn.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1019&context=think_tanks (Target area 1).
